content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: Adobe Acrobat uses AI to turn your PDFs into podcasts
entries.snippet: Adobe has introduced new generative AI features to its Acrobat software, specifically within the separate Acrobat Studio app, enhancing how users interact with PDF documents. These updates include tools for chat-based editing, and the ability to create personalized podcasts and pitch presentations from PDF content. The "Generate Podcast" feature provides audio summaries of documents—like notes, reports, and transcripts—using a Microsoft GPT model for transcription and a Google voice model, although Adobe may switch to its proprietary models later. Additionally, the "Generate Presentation" feature leverages Adobe Express tools to create visual summaries with editable presentation templates. Users can guide the AI to focus on specific insights in the documents. The Acrobat AI assistant also now supports in-document edits through natural language prompts, enabling actions such as adding signatures, removing or modifying text, and other PDF alterations—similar to features introduced to Adobe Express in 2025.

entries.title: Transcribe audio with Google Gemini for free - here's how to do it
entries.snippet: Google Gemini now offers a free tool for transcribing audio files up to 10 minutes long. Users can upload up to 10 audio files at once, provided their combined length doesn't exceed the time limit. Compatible formats include MP3, AAC, and WAV. To begin, users can access Gemini via its website or app, select the upload option, and choose their desired audio file. Once uploaded, a prompt like "transcribe this speech" initiates the process. If an error occurs, retrying usually resolves the issue. Transcriptions are generated quickly, though they may include filler words (e.g., "uhms" and "ahs"). Users can instruct Gemini to clean the transcript by prompting it to remove such filler words. Additionally, Gemini can help summarize the audio or extract key points, making it a versatile tool for various transcription needs.

entries.title: Save $300 on AI caption and transcription platform Joyspace, now $79.99
entries.snippet:
The article promotes a significant discount on a lifetime subscription to Joyspace, an AI-powered captioning and transcription platform, now available for $79.99 (originally $379). Joyspace allows users to automatically generate captions for videos and transcribe recordings or podcasts using AI. With the Essential Plan, subscribers receive 80 minutes of transcription and 160 credits per month, as well as a 45-minute video export limit.

The plan also includes features such as watermark-free video, downloadable transcripts, instant captions, unlimited downloads and templates, and access to B-roll media like images and GIFs. Supporting 35 languages, Joyspace makes it easy to work with multi-lingual content without needing bilingual services. The platform allows customization of captions to match brand aesthetics and offers tools like animated emojis and timing adjustments for readability.

Beyond accessibility for the hearing-impaired, captions support silent viewing and content virality. Joyspace aims to streamline content creation for webinars, podcasts, and videos, helping creators maximize reach and user engagement.

entries.title: Transkriptor.com
Transkriptor
Otter.ai App Adds French and Spanish Transcription: What You Need to Know
entries.snippet:
Otter.ai has expanded its capabilities by adding real-time transcription support for French and Spanish, in addition to English. The app, available on both Android and iOS, allows users to record and transcribe meetings and conversations directly from their mobile device or through a web interface that integrates with platforms like Zoom, Microsoft Teams, and Google Meet. However, it does not offer translation services, so users must be fluent in the chosen language.

The app is free with a Basic plan offering 300 transcription minutes per month (30 minutes per conversation) and limits to three imported files. The Pro plan, costing $16.99/month or $100 annually, raises these limits to 1200 minutes per month, 90 minutes per conversation, and up to 10 imported files. Business and Enterprise plans are also available for users needing more extensive features. Users can edit transcriptions to correct any errors.

entries.title: RecCloud
Transkriptor
I make $3,300 a month with my 'nighttime' side hustle - I only work 10 to 30 hours a week and don't even leave my home
entries.snippet: An entrepreneur named Arianna Anglin has revealed how she earns $3,300 a month from a low-commitment, remote side hustle: transcription. Done entirely from home and in the evenings, this job requires only 10 to 30 hours of work per week and involves converting audio or video recordings into written text. Anglin shares her experiences and tips with her nearly 500,000 TikTok followers and recommends the company Daily Transcription, which currently hires freelancers for positions like General Transcriber, AI Editor, Medical Transcriber, and Captioner. Pay ranges from $45 to $66 per media hour, potentially yielding $825 per week if working 15 hours at an average rate of $55/hour. Some users raised concerns about the accuracy of the pay structure and the need to take a transcription course; others noted that experience can eliminate the need for training. Despite the concerns, the opportunity stands out as a lucrative and flexible option for those seeking extra income.

v.title: Gemini just got a new highly-requested feature that trumps ChatGPT
v.snippet:
Google's Gemini AI assistant has introduced a highly requested feature: the ability to upload and process audio files, offering transcription, summaries, and key highlights. This new feature allows users to easily convert voice memos or meeting recordings into searchable, actionable content, effectively acting as a personal note-taker. However, it currently supports only up to 10 minutes of audio per file, and free-tier users have limited daily usage.

Unlike Gemini Live, which handles real-time voice interaction, this update focuses on processing pre-recorded audio files for in-depth analysis. Users can upload audio via the standard file options on the web or mobile app and receive transcriptions, speaker-specific information, simplified summaries, to-do items, and even auto-generated study guides.

This functionality aligns with recent Gemini enhancements, including improved personalization and visual upgrades, and brings it on par—or possibly ahead—of AI rivals like ChatGPT’s Whisper model and Anthropic’s Claude. Reviewers praised Gemini's accuracy and usability, especially for everyday scenarios. Google hasn’t detailed pricing for extensive use but hinted the feature falls under the standard Gemini quota.

entries.title: Careless Whisper: Speech-to-Text Hallucination Harms

v.title: SANTLR: Speech Annotation Toolkit for Low Resource Languages

entries.title: Researchers say an AI-powered transcription tool used in hospitals invents things no one ever said
entries.snippet:
A growing concern is emerging over OpenAI's AI-powered transcription tool, Whisper, which is being used widely across industries including healthcare. Despite being praised for near-human level accuracy, experts have found that Whisper frequently introduces false or fabricated text, known as "hallucinations." These hallucinations can include imagined treatments, racial references, and violent statements—even in clear, short audio clips. Researchers have found hallucinations in up to 80% of transcripts studied, raising alarm about its use in sensitive fields like medicine.

Whisper is already integrated into systems run by companies like Microsoft and Oracle and is used by over 30,000 clinicians through a Whisper-based medical tool developed by Nabla. Critics, including former OpenAI employees and academic researchers, warn that these errors can be dangerous in high-risk domains such as healthcare, especially since some hospitals erase original audio, removing a reference point for verification. OpenAI acknowledges the flaw and says it is working on improvements but advises against using Whisper in critical decision-making contexts. Lawmakers and patient advocates express additional concern over privacy issues tied to the use of sensitive audio by large tech platforms.
